Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story: I woke up early, heart pounding with anticipation and dread. It was the last weekend before Alex left for his new job overseas, and we’d promised ourselves a day just for us—no distractions, just memories to hold onto. He smiled at me over breakfast, his hand warm in mine, and I felt the weight of time slipping away. But as I was about to leave for the salon, my phone buzzed: the bride and her bridesmaids had arrived early, nerves fraying, desperate for reassurance and a calming touch. My boss texted, “We need you now. They’re anxious.” I looked at Alex, who was already planning our day, and then at my uniform, hanging by the door. My heart twisted. I wanted to be the girlfriend he needed, to soak up every last moment. But I was also the hairdresser, expected to greet my clients with a smile, to make their special day perfect. The demands pulled me in opposite directions, and I stood frozen, torn between love and duty, wishing I could be in two places at once.
